The Small Claims Division: Local Court Practice Guide

level.toc-caption: The Small Claims Division: Local Court Practice Guide

heading.title: The Small Claims Division: Local Court Practice Guide

p.text: The procedures applicable in the Small Claims Division may be found in the Civil Procedure Act 2005 (CPA), the Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 (UCPR), LCA 2007 Pt 3 Div 3 “Proceedings in Small Claims Division”, Pt 2 Div 2 of the Local Court Rules 2009 (LCR 2009), and Practice Note Civ 1 “Case Management of Civil Proceedings in the Local Court” at [LC Civ 1 of 2011], reissued 7 January 2013 (Amended 4 March 2013) cll 19–24. The following commentary endeavours to draw together these disparate sources and procedures and to make them applicable to situations which may be experienced in practice when preparing or presenting a matter in the Small Claims Division (SCD). In so saying, it should be noted that, apart from the Act itself, there are many rules, Practice Notes, and Case Management Orders which say exactly the same or similar thing in effect: For example:

Each of the parties to the proceedings must be in attendance at the review, either in person or by a legal representative having authority to negotiate a settlement of the proceedings: LCR 2009 r 2.5(1) ; see also Practice Note Civ 1 “Case Management of Civil Proceedings in the Local Court” at [LC Civ 1 of 2011], cl 20.4.

The parties may apply for any interlocutory orders necessary for the preparation of the matter for trial: LCR 2009 r 2.5(3) . See also Practice Note Civ 1 “Case Management of Civil Proceedings in the Local Court” at [LC Civ 1 of 2011], cl 20.7 “The parties “are required” to make any interlocutory applications at the Pre-trial Review”; also cl 21: subject to leave and unless the court otherwise orders, interlocutory applications in the SCD are to be made orally at the PTR (LCR r 2.10 ).

The court must identify the matters in dispute between the parties and attempt to bring the parties to a settlement that is acceptable to them, and for that purpose, may require that the parties seek mediation: LCR 2009 r 2.5(4) . (See also Practice Note Civ 1 “Case Management of Civil Proceedings in the Local Court” at [LC Civ 1 of 2011], cl 20.3).

Proceedings in the SCD are to be conducted with as little formality and technicality as the proper consideration of the matter permits: LCA 2007 s 35(2) . See also Practice Note Civ 1 “Case Management of Civil Proceedings in the Local Court” at [LC Civ 1 of 2011], cl 19.2

Procedure is to be determined by the court: LCR 2009 r 2.6(1) . See also Practice Note Civ 1 “Case Management of Civil Proceedings in the Local Court” at [LC Civ 1 of 2011], cl 23.6: “The procedure at the trial of the proceedings in the Small Claims Division will be determined by the Magistrate or Assessor as he or she thinks fit”.
The rules of evidence do not apply to proceedings being heard or other proceedings in the SCD: LCA 2007 s 35(3) .

level.toc-caption: [22,001] Object of the Small Claims Division in the context of the CPA

p.text: Legislation cited in [22,001] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 56(1).

heading.title: Object of the Small Claims Division in the context of the CPA

p.text: Legislation cited in [22,005] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Local Court Act 2007 s 17, s 30, s 30(5), s 35(1), Sch 2.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 3, s 57(1).
(NSW) Judicial Officers Act 1986 s 3.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 36.3.

The source of jurisdiction of the Small Claims Division is LCA 2007 s 30 . The jurisdictional limit of a Local Court sitting in its Small Claims Division is $10,000. It has remained at that level since 25 September 2000.
If:
the jurisdictional limit of a Division is increased; and
proceedings in which an amount of money is claimed are pending in a court when that increase takes effect,
the court may, on the application of a plaintiff, make an order altering the amount specified in the claim to an amount not exceeding the new jurisdictional limit: LCA 2007 s 30(5) .

The jurisdiction of a court sitting in its Small Claims Division may be exercised by a magistrate or an assessor: LCA 2007 s 35(1) . The appointment and qualifications for assessors are described in LCA 2007 s 17 and Sch 2 . Although assessors do not fall within the definition of “judicial officer” in CPA s 3 (or in Judicial Officers Act 1986 s 3 ), “this is merely due to legislative oversight (and) .. it is appropriate to assume that an Assessor is bound, and has authority, to proceed in accordance with the procedure (concerning the giving of reserved judgments) under [UCPR] r 36.3 ”: McClymont v The Owners-Strata Plan No 12139 [2009] NSWSC 276; BC200902727 at [59] per McCallum J.

The court will case manage the proceedings having regard to the objects specified in CPA s 57(1) : Practice Note Civ 1 “Case Management of Civil Proceedings in the Local Court” at [LC Civ 1 of 2011], cl 19.1.

level.toc-caption: [22,010] Commencing and carrying on proceedings in the Small Claims Division

p.text: Legislation cited in [22,010] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Legal Profession Act 2004 Pt 3.2.
(NSW) Strata Schemes Management Act 1996 s 80.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 101(2)(h).
(CTH) Bankruptcy Act 1966 Pt X.
(NSW) Local Courts (Civil Claims) Act 1970 s 11, s 23B(1), s 69(2A).

heading.title: Commencing and carrying on proceedings in the Small Claims Division

p.text: Proceedings are commenced in the Small Claims Division in the same manner as in the General Division. Documents are prepared and pleaded in the same manner, and UCPR Pt 4 , which deals with the preparation, signature, filing and service of documents, applies in its entirety in the Small Claims Division. Note that the originating process and any subsequent documentation must bear the words “Small Claims Division” as an endorsement on the process. This is the effect of r 4.2(1)(b) and r 4.2(2)(b) , which requires a statement of the Division in which the proceedings are intended to be heard to be endorsed thereon. The endorsement will generally appear adjacent to, or underneath, the statement of the relevant court in which the proceedings are to be heard.

UCPR Pt 6 , dealing with commencing proceedings and appearance, also applies in the SCD. The venue where the proceedings are intended to be heard must be stated: r 4.2(1)(c) . The rules relating to joinder of causes of action and of parties, for example where common questions of law and fact are involved, also apply in the SCD: Pt 6 Div 5 .

Under UCPR Pt 14 , matters are pleaded in the SCD in the same manner as in the General Division (GD), except that there is no provision for the filing of a reply or subsequent pleading in the SCD: by virtue of UCPR rr 1.5 and 1.6 and Sch 1, Column 4, rr 14.4 and 14.5 (dealing with reply and further pleadings) do not apply in the SCD. As a result of r 14.23 , which applies only in the Supreme Court and in the District Court, it would appear that pleadings are not required to be verified by affidavit in either Division of the Local Court. The same rules apply to proceedings by or against persons operating business names, be they registered or unregistered, as in the GD: UCPR Pt 7 Div 5 , r 7.19 ff. The same rules also apply to cross-claims in the SCD as in the GD: Pt 9 . UCPR Pt 19 dealing with amendment also applies in the SCD.

Matters are particularised in same manner in the SCD as in the GD pursuant to UCPR Pt 15 , with the exception of Division 2, which deals particularisation in personal injury cases. Further UCPR rr 15.7 and 15.8 , dealing with the need to particularise claims for exemplary and aggravated damages, also do not apply in the SCD: UCPR rr 1.5 and 1.6 , Sch 1 column 4.

By virtue of UCPR Pt 7 , parties are entitled to be represented in the SCD in the same manner as in the GD. See in particular r 7.1(1) , which sets out by whom proceedings may be commenced and carried on: a natural person may commence and carry on proceedings either by a solicitor acting on his or her behalf or in person; and r 7.1(2) , by virtue of which a company may commence and carry on proceedings by a director. In the Local Court a company may also commence and, unless the court orders otherwise, carry on proceedings by a duly authorised officer or employee: r 7.1(2)(b) . Note also r 7.1(5) as to who, despite r 7.5 , may commence and carry on proceedings in the Local Court in certain types of enforcement proceedings. As to the appointment and removal of solicitors, see UCPR rr 7.24 – 31 . The same rules apply as in the General Division. At the Pre-Trial Review, any party who is legally represented must have authority to settle the dispute: Practice Note Civ 1 “Case Management of Civil Proceedings in the Local Court” at [LC Civ 1 of 2011], reissued 7 January 2013, Amended 7 March 2013, cl 6.

level.toc-caption: [22,010.20] Discontinuance and withdrawal, dismissal and setting aside

heading.title: Discontinuance and withdrawal, dismissal and setting aside

p.text: The same rules also apply as regards discontinuance of proceedings, withdrawal of appearance or pleading, dismissal for lack of progress, and setting aside of originating process: UCPR Pt 12 . The provisions regarding costs in proceedings discontinued or dismissed are set out in rr 42.19 and 42.20 . See also LCR 2009 r 2.9(2) .
If within 9 months after a statement of claim has been filed:
a defence or cross claim is not filed, or
a default judgment is not entered, or
the proceedings are not otherwise disposed of,

the proceedings are, on the court’s own motion and order dismissed (UCPR r 12.9(2) ). No such order is made if there are any Notices of Motion or other applications in the proceedings that are yet to be determined (UCPR r 12.9(4) : Practice Note Civ 1 “Case Management of Civil Proceedings in the Local Court” at [LC Civ 1 of 2011], cl 7.1.

Following an amendment to Sch 1 of the UCPR (Amendment No 10 of 2006, r 2 and Sch 1[27], effective 7 July 2006), subpoenas under UCPR r 33.2 may now be issued in the Small Claims Division (“SCD”). This recognises the fact that the increasing complexity of matters in the Division may justify the issue of subpoenas in appropriate circumstances. The rule makers opine that the combined effect of rr 7.3 and 33.2 is that the Registrar has the power to issue a subpoena in the Small Claims Division; see also “Delegated powers of Registrars” at [21,000] . As to procedural fairness involving documents admitted under subpoena on the day of the hearing when the other party is denied the opportunity to adequately respond and call evidence in reply: see Wende v Finney [2005] NSWSC 927; BC200506931 , noted also at [22,010.110] . In the SCD, a subpoena may be issued only with leave of the court (UCPR r 7.3 ). See also Practice Note Civ 1 "Case Management of Civil Proceedings in the Local Court" at [LC Civ 1 of 2011], cl 26.1: Application for a subpoena should be made at the PTR: cl 26.2.

The same procedures apply as regards manner of service of documents, including the rules regarding personal service, substituted and informal service, in the SCD as in the GD: UCPR Pt 10 . Note in particular UCPR r 10.8 relating to service of Local Court process by an officer of the court. As to service on an unregistered business name see r 10.9 , and where the business name is registered, r 10.10 .

The court may make an order changing the proceedings if it thinks it appropriate in the circumstances: LCA 2007 s 55 . Changes of venue are dealt with under UCPR rr 8.1, 8.2 . An application for a change of venue under UCPR Pt 8 is to be made by motion in accordance with UCPR Pt 18 : LCR 2009 r 2.10 .

level.toc-caption: [22,010.37] Transfer of proceedings between the SCD and the GD

heading.title: Transfer of proceedings between the SCD and the GD

p.text: If the court’s jurisdictional limit in the SCD is exceeded, proceedings are to be transferred from the SCD to the GD if a cross-claim is made in the proceedings for an amount exceeding the jurisdictional limit of the SCD: LCR 2009 r 2.2 . The court may, on the application of a party or of its own motion, transfer proceedings to the GD if, at any time before judgment is given, the court is of the opinion that the matters in dispute are so complex or difficult, or are of such importance, that the proceedings ought more properly to be heard in the GD: LCR 2009 r 2.3 . See also Practice Note Civ 1 “Case Management of Civil Proceedings in the Local Court” at [LC Civ 1 of 2011], cl 9.1, which provides that in addition to the matters contained in r 2.3 , “the court may transfer proceedings from the Small Claims Division to the General Division where it considers that the proceedings should be consolidated with other proceedings already commenced in the General Division”. The court may, on the application of a party or of its own motion, transfer proceedings thus transferred to the GD back to its SCD if the court considers it appropriate to do so. An application for proceedings to be thus transferred may not be made by a party to the proceedings later than 28 days before the day fixed for the trial of the proceedings: LCR 2009 r 2.3 .

Despite LCR 2009 r 2.3(1) , the SCD does not lack jurisdiction to hear disputes which are complex or difficult. The substance of the rule “indicates that the Court’s opinion as to the complexity, difficulty or importance of the matters in dispute is not the measure of its jurisdiction”: McClymont v The Owners-Strata Plan No 12139 [2009] NSWSC 276; BC200902727 at [19] per McCallum J.

The procedures governing the pre-trial review and trial in the Small Claims Division are set out in Practice Note Civ 1 “Case Management of Civil Proceedings in the Local Court” at [LC Civ 1 of 2011], cl 20. The following provisions are also applicable:

Setting down for pre-trial review Unless the court otherwise orders, proceedings in which a defence is filed are to be listed for PTR. The registrar must cause notice of the date, time and place of the PTR to be sent to the plaintiff and to each defendant who has filed a defence: LCR 2009 r 2.4 . The proceedings are given a PTR date within 6 weeks of the filing of a first defence: PN 2 of 2005 cl 9.1.

Conduct of the PTR The object of the PTR is to provide the opportunity for the court to assist the parties to settle their dispute: Practice Note Civ 1 “Case Management of Civil Proceedings in the Local Court” at [LC Civ 1 of 2011], cl 20.3.

Each of the parties to the proceedings must be in attendance at the review, either in person or by a legal representative having authority to negotiate a settlement of the proceedings: LCR 2009 r 2.5(1)(a) (See also Practice Note Civ 1 “Case Management of Civil Proceedings in the Local Court” at [LC Civ 1 of 2011], cl 6 to similar effect). Each party must disclose the names of the witnesses who may provide statements on which the party intends to rely at the trial and the nature of any other documents on which the party intends to rely at the trial (to the extent that such information is available at the time of the PTR): LCR 2009 r 2.5(1)(b) . Any application for a party or witness to be given leave to appear by telephone or AVL at the trial must be made at the time the proceedings are listed for hearing: PN Civ 1 of 2011, cl 24.1. As to the obligations which follow, see cl 24.2. A person who appears by telephone, audio-visual link or any other means of electronic communication, as referred to in LCR 2009 r 2.8 , is taken to be in attendance: LCR 2009 r 2.5(2) .

The parties may apply for any interlocutory orders necessary for the preparation of the matter for trial: LCR 2009 r 2.5(3) . See also Practice Note Civ 1 “Case Management of Civil Proceedings in the Local Court” at [LC Civ 1 of 2011], cll 5, 20.7.

The court must identify the matters in dispute between the parties and attempt to bring the parties to a settlement that is acceptable to them, and for that purpose, may require that the parties seek mediation: LCR 2009 r 2.5(4). Compare Practice Note Civ 1 “Case Management of Civil Proceedings in the Local Court” at [LC Civ 1 of 2011], cl 20.3, 20.5: “The court may refer the parties to mediation”.
If the parties agree to seek mediation, the court may make such orders as it thinks fit, including orders as to adjournment, so as to facilitate the mediation: LCR 2009 r 2.5(5) .

If the court is unable to bring the parties to a settlement that is acceptable to them, the court is to list the proceedings for trial at an appropriate time and venue and make case management orders in accordance with any relevant practice note. However, the court may refuse to list proceedings for trial if it is satisfied that the parties have not made reasonable attempts to settle the matters in dispute between them: LCR 2009 r 2.5(6) .

If the matter is not settled at the PTR, the parties must identify the matters in dispute and disclose, so far as is known, the statements and documents upon which they propose to rely at the hearing. The parties shall record these matters on the PTR Sheet, Annexure C to LC Civ 1 of 2011 and lodge the same with the registrar at the PTR: Practice Note Civ 1, cl 20.6.
Unless the court otherwise orders, the Case Management Order given by the magistrate, assessor or registrar at the PTR shall be in accordance with Annexure D to LC Civ 1 of 2011: cl 20.9.

Attendance of witnesses to give oral evidence In determining whether a direction may be given at the PTR that a witness attend the trial of the proceedings to be orally examined, the magistrate, assessor or registrar will have regard to the particular circumstances of the case, including the amount involved and whether there is a real issue as to credibility or a significant conflict in the evidence: Practice Note Civ 1 of 2011, cl 20.8.

A party will not be permitted to rely on documents or statements at the hearing that have not been filed and served in accordance with the Case Management Order unless the court grants leave: Practice Note Civ 1 of 2011, cl 20.10.

Assessment of damages in undefended proceedings In proceedings in which default judgment has been entered in favour of the plaintiff but damages are yet to be assessed, the court may, when listing the proceedings for trial, give directions as to the manner in which evidence as to damages is to be given: LCR 2009 r 2.7 .

level.toc-caption: [22,010.45] Consequences of failure to attend the PTR

heading.title: Consequences of failure to attend the PTR

p.text: If a party fails to attend the PTR after having been given notice in accordance with rule LCR 2009 r 2.4(2) , the court may adjourn the review to another date and direct that, not less than 5 days before that date, a further notice be given to the party in default advising:
if the party in default is the plaintiff, that the party’s claim may be dismissed, either in whole or in part; or
if the party in default is the defendant, that the party’s defence may be struck out, either in whole or in part, if the party fails to attend the adjourned review: LCR 2009 r 2.5(7) .
If a party fails to attend the adjourned review after having been given such notice, the court may order:
if the party in default is the plaintiff, that the party’s claim be dismissed, either in whole or in part; or
if the party in default is the defendant, that the party’s defence be struck out, either in whole or in part,
and may make such other orders as it thinks fit: LCR 2009 r 2.5(8) .

level.toc-caption: [22,010.50] Procedure at trial and generally in the SCD

heading.title: Procedure at trial and generally in the SCD

p.text: Proceedings in the SCD are to be conducted with as little formality and technicality as the proper consideration of the matter permits: LCA 2007 s 35(2) ; Practice Note Civ 1 of 2011, cl 19.2.
Other than the judgment or order made, the proceedings are not required to be recorded: LCA 2007 s 35(6) .
The assessor or magistrate may inform himself or herself on any matter relating to proceedings being heard or other proceedings in the SCD in such manner as he or she thinks fit: LCA 2007 s 35(5) .

Procedure is to be determined by the court: LCR 2009 r 2.6(1) . See also Practice Note Civ 1 of 2011, cl 23.6: “The procedure at the trial of the proceedings in the Small Claims Division will be determined by the Magistrate or Assessor as he or she thinks fit”.

Unless the court orders otherwise, proceedings are to be heard and determined on the basis of the documentary evidence that has been filed and served in accordance with the case management order (Standard Case Management Order 1, Annexure D to Practice Note Civ 1 of 2011); and any submissions made by the parties on the material filed and served in accordance with any case management orders: LCR 2009 r 2.6(2) ; compare Practice Note Civ 1 of 2011, cl 23.3. The court may allow any documents produced under subpoena issued with the leave of the court or produced under a Notice to Produce to be admitted as evidence: standard Case Management Order 2.

The written statements and other documentary material must be filed at the Local Court Registry and exchanged between the parties no later than the date specified in the Case Management Order, being a date no later than 14 days before the hearing: Annexure D to Practice Note Civ 1 of 2011, cl 1. If a party fails to do so the court may refuse to allow the party to rely on that evidence at the hearing: Annexure B to Practice Note Civ 1 of 2011, cl 3.
Proceedings may be heard and determined by the court even if one or more of the parties is absent: LCR 2009 r 2.6(3) .

A ‘formal trial’ that is the normal adversarial trial where evidence is taken on oath and witnesses cross-examined, is not available in the SCD: Practice Note Civ 1 of 2011, cl 23.1. Subject to any direction of the court, there is no right to call witnesses to give evidence or to cross-examine witnesses or for a party to give evidence at the hearing: cl 23.2; CPA s 62(4)(d) ; LCA 2007 s 35(4) . For judicial pronouncements on the denial of the right to cross-examine, see [22,010.115] .

Where a direction has not been given at the PTR by the magistrate, assessor or registrar for the attendance or cross-examination of any witness at the trial of the proceedings, the proceedings will be heard and determined in open court on the basis of the documentary evidence and filed in accordance with the Case Management Order. Parties have the right to attend and make comments, present arguments and make final submissions on the evidence: Practice Note Civ 1 of 2011, cll 23.3, 23.5; Case Management Order, Annexure D to Practice Note Civ 1 of 2011, cl 5.

Where a direction has been given at the PTR by the magistrate, assessor or registrar that a witness attend for cross-examination, the proceedings will be heard and determined on the oral evidence and the written submissions and other documents and materials which have been tendered. The party relying on the statement of the witness is responsible for securing his attandanece: Practice Note Civ 1 of 2011, cl 23.4. Comments, arguments and final submission on the evidence will also be allowed: Practice Note Civ 1 of 2011, cl 23.5.
The rules of evidence do not apply to proceedings being heard or other proceedings in the SCD: LCA 2007 s 35(3) .

UCPR Pt 31 (Evidence) and Pt 33 (Subpoenas) do not apply in the SCD: UCPR rr 1.4 and 1.6 , Sch 1 column 4. Since Pt 31 does not apply, neither also do the provisions relating to an expert’s adherence to the code of conduct specified in UCPR r 31.17 . However, if preparing a written statement by an expert, it would be good practice for the expert to adhere to the code of conduct.

A subpoena may not be issued in relation to proceedings in the SCD, “except by leave of the court, in any circumstances”: UCPR r 7.3(3) ; but see [22,010.25] . However, a party in the SCD may give another party notice to produce any specified document or thing to the court or to any examiner under UCPR Pt 34 . UCPR Pt 20 Divs 1 (Mediation), 2 (Arbitration), 3 (Reference to referees) and 4 (Compromise) do not apply in the SCD: UCPR rr 1.5 and 1.6 , Sch 1 , column 4. (Note incidentally that an order for rehearing of proceedings referred to arbitration may not be made unless the amount claimed in the proceedings, or the value of the property to which the proceedings relate exceeds the jurisdictional limit of a Local Court when sitting in its SCD: CPA s 43(2) .

CPA s 70 (court’s power to dispense with the rules of evidence for proving matters not bona fide in dispute and to order a party to make admissions), and s 87 (protection against self-incrimination in relation to interlocutory matters) do not apply in the SCD: UCPR rr 1.5 and 1.6 , Sch 1 column 3.

Use of telephones, audio-visual link and other electronic communication In any proceedings, the court may allow a person to appear or give evidence by telephone, audio-visual link or any other means of electronic communication: LCR 2009 r 2.8 ; see also PN LC Civ 1 of 2011, cl 24, noted at [22,010.40] .
Vacating a trial date A notice of motion must be filed not less than 21 days prior to the trial date if “unforeseen circumatances” arise: PN Civ 1 of 2011, cll 22.1, 22.2.

In the Small Claims Division, the affidavit in support of the application for default judgment may be sworn by the party’s solicitor, or by a commercial agent of subagent (within the meaning of the Commercial Agents and Private Inquiry Agents Act 1963: r 35.3(2)(a)(v).

A defendant is “in default” for the purposes of UCPR Pt 16 if the defendant fails to file a defence within time, or fails to file an affidavit verifying his or her defence in accordance with the rules, or having filed a defence, the court orders it to be struck out. The procedure to follow where a defendant is in default is set out in r 16.3 .

If the defendant’s claim against a defendant in default is for unliquidated damages only, judgment may be entered for the plaintiff against the defendant for damages to be assessed and for costs: UCPR r 16.7(1) . Part 30 contains provisions as regards the assessment of damages, and r 16.7 contains provisions for the requirements of the relevant affidavit to support the assessment. In proceedings in which default judgment has been entered in favour of the plaintiff but damages are yet to be assessed, the court may, when listing the proceedings for trial, give directions as to the manner in which evidence as to damages is to be given: LCR 2009 r 2.7 .

The assessor or magistrate is not to give judgment or make a final order in respect of proceedings being heard in the SCD unless the assessor or magistrate has brought, or has used his or her best endeavours to bring, the parties to the proceedings to a settlement acceptable to the parties. If such a settlement is reached, the assessor or magistrate is to give judgment or make a final order that gives effect to the terms of the settlement: LCA 2007 s 36(1)–(2) .

CPA s 92 (judgments for possession of land) does not apply in the SCD: UCPR rr 1.5 and 1.6 , Sch 1 column 3. UCPR Pt 36 “Judgments and orders” applies in the SCD, with the exception of r 36.8 “Possession of land”, and, as already noted rr 36.15 and 36.16 dealing with the court’s general and further powers to set aside a judgment or order.

UCPR r 36.3 confers authority on the Local Court to give judgment in respect of a reserved decision other than in open court, provided that the requirements of that rule are strictly complied with, and subject to the requirement of procedural fairness to give advance notice to the parties of that event. The procedure of giving judgment in the absence of the public ought to be confined to disposal in chambers of undefended actions: Palmer v Clarke (1989) 19 NSWLR 158 at 167E per Kirby P. However, pursuant to the express words of UCPR r 36.3(1) , it is not impermissible in other circumstances: McClymont v The Owners-Strata Plan No 12139 [2009] NSWSC 276; BC200902727 at [69] per McCallum J (although the failure to give notice that the judgment was to be handed down constituted a denial of natural justice it made no difference to the outcome and did not warrant the matter being referred back to the Local Court for a new hearing).
The slip rule applies in the SCD: UCPR r 36.17 .
The SCD has no power to make an order for interim payments under CPA Pt 6 Div 5 : UCPR rr 1.5 and 1.6 and Sch 1 column 3.

By virtue of UCPR rr 1.5 and 1.6 and Sch 1, column 4, Pt 18 (“Motions”) is expressed not to apply in the SCD except in relation to an application under r 23.8 (Inspection of Property), r 36.15 (general power to set aside judgment or order on sufficient cause if the judgment was given or entered, or the order was made, irregularly, illegally or against good faith), r 36.16 (further power to set aside or vary judgment or order if notice of motion is filed before entry of the judgment or order, or after it has been entered in certain other circumstances as set out in r 36.16(2) , or r 43.6 dealing with interpleader motions. Unless the court otherwise orders or leave is granted, interlocutory applications in the SCD are to be made orally at the pre-trial review: PN Civ 1 of 2011, cl 21.
LCR 2009 r 2.10 states that “unless the court orders otherwise, applications are to be made orally before the court”. The stated exceptions in r 2.10 are:
any application for the transfer of proceedings to the GD, or
any application for an order under UCPR Pt 8 that the venue be changed, or
any application in relation to proceedings made after the court has given judgment in the proceedings (such as an application for a writ of execution); or
any application to set aside a judgment or order of the court.
Such applications are to be made by motion in accordance with UCPR Pt 18 .

level.toc-caption: [22,010.80] Applications to set aside default judgment

heading.title: Applications to set aside default judgment

p.text: It would appear from cl 12(2)(c) and (d) that any application to set aside a judgment be it recorded by default, in the absence of a defendant, by agreement under UCPR r 20.33 or on the basis that the judgment was entered irregularly, illegally or against good faith may be made on motion in the Small Claims Division. (Note that a judgment by agreement entered under UCPR r 20.33(2) may be set aside on sufficient cause being shown on the application of any party to the proceedings who was not a party to the agreement under UCPR r 20.33(7) ). Until now, the Local Courts (Civil Claims) Rules 1988 Pt 3 r 11 provided that if the judgment was entered after a hearing when both parties appeared, any application to set it aside should be made in the SCD. Otherwise, such applications were to be made in the GD. Also falling within (c) above are applications made under r 36.18 for the variation of a judgment or an order against a party operating under a business name so as to make it a judgment or order against the person in the person's own name.

It seems to have been assumed (without the issue being raised in the judgment) in Gorczynski v Holden [2008] NSWSC 334; BC200802606 that such an exercise (an application to set aside a default judgment) was properly entertained in the Small Claims Division. The court went on to hold that a court entertaining such an application in the Small Claims Division has the power to set aside a judgment “on terms” under CPA s 86 , including the power to make it dependant upon the payment of costs as to other (bankruptcy) proceedings and the payment of moneys into court. The fact that UCPR Pt 41 (dealing with the payment of money into court) did not apply in the SCD was therefore irrelevant.
A Local Court may not order the payment of interest up to judgment in any proceedings in which the amount claimed is less than $1000: UCPR r 36.7(2) .

CPA s 106 “Judgments for payment of money” applies in the SCD. So far as is here relevant, under s 106(1) a judgment debt may be enforced by means of any one or more of (a) a writ for the levy of property, (b) a garnishee order. Under s 106(5) , the Sheriff’s power to sell land may not be exercised in relation to land if the amount outstanding under the judgment is less than the jurisdictional limit of a Local Court when sitting in its Small Claims Division. Somewhat curiously, CPA s 130 (judgments or orders not enforceable by attachment or committal of the person or by writ of ca sa) is expressed not to apply in the SCD: rr 1.5 and 1.6 , and Sch 1, column 3.

UCPR Pts 37 and 38 “Time to pay and payment by instalments” and “Examination of judgment debtor etc) both apply in the SCD, as does Pt 39 “Enforcement of judgments”, with the exception of Div 2 “Enforcement of judgments against land”.
The court may make orders for the payment of costs (which expression includes fees, disbursements, expenses and remuneration) only in the following circumstances:
if proceedings are discontinued or dismissed, or a defence is struck out, at a pre-trial review or at a hearing;
if proceedings are adjourned as a consequence of a party’s default or neglect, including a party’s failure to comply with a direction of the court;
if proceedings on a motion are heard by the court; and
if judgment is given after a trial of proceedings: LCR 2009 r 2.9(1), 2.9(2) .
The maximum amount of costs that may be awarded to a party under LCR 2009 r 2.9(2) is the amount of costs that would be allowable on entry of default judgment in the proceedings: LCR 2009 r 2.9(3) .
Despite LCR 2009 r 2.9(2) and (3), the court may also allow costs for the following:
court and service fees;
fees for expert opinion reports (limited to a maximum of $100 for each report); and
search fees.

CPA s 60 , which says that the practice and procedure of the court should be implemented with the object of resolving the issues between the parties in such a way that the cost to the parties is proportionate to the importance and complexity of the subject-matter in dispute, does not apply in the SCD: UCPR rr 1.5 and 1.6 , Sch 1 column 3.

The Local Court sitting in its Small Claims Division has no power to order the payment of a party’s expenses of travel and loss of time: Arnoldus-Lewis v Murphy [2008] NSWSC 1103; BC200809350 . An appeal to the Court of Appeal was unsuccessful: Murphy v Arnoldus-Lewis [2009] NSWCA 142; BC200904994 .

The Court of Appeal’s decision in Owners of Strata Plan 36131 v Dimitriou [2009] NSWCA 27; BC200900947 is authority for the proposition that the Small Claims Division of the Local Court does not lack jurisdiction to determine an owners corporation’s claim under Strata Schemes Management Act 1996 s 80 for its legal costs incurred in recovering unpaid contributions: McClymont v The Owners-Strata Plan No 12139 [2009] NSWSC 276; BC200902727 at [29] per McCallum J.

UCPR Pt 43 , which prescribes the procedure to follow as regards stakeholder’s interpleader and Sheriff’s interpleader applies in the SCD. UCPR r 43.6 dealing with interpleader motions on a Sheriff’s interpleader falls within LC(CP)R r 12(2)(c) , thereby facilitating an application by motion under r 43.6 . This is one of the exceptions to the embargo on motions generally in the SCD: see UCPR rr 1.5 and 1.6 , Sch 1 column 4.

A party to proceedings who is dissatisfied with the judgment or order of a Court sitting in its Small Claims Division may appeal to the Supreme Court against the judgment or order, but only on the ground of lack of jurisdiction or denial of procedural fairness: LCA 2007 s 39(2) .

There will be no appeal of any kind from the decisions of the Small Claims Division other than for lack of jurisdiction or denial of natural justice. The prohibition of appeals is quite necessary if a party is to be able to litigate in the division without the risk of suddenly escalating costs. It is also fair to argue that if the taxpayer is to fund a forum for people who decide to litigate over small matters, it should be a once-only forum and the public purse should not have to contribute the immense costs of providing an appellate procedure: Attorney-General's Second Reading speech to the Legislative Assembly, Hansard, 22 November 1990, p 10416.

level.toc-caption: [22,010.110] What constitutes a denial of procedural fairness?

heading.title: What constitutes a denial of procedural fairness?

p.text: Note: The concept was described as a denial of natural justice in LCA 1982 s 73(2) , but these twin concepts appear to be used interchangeably. The decisions reviewed below are equally applicable in both circumstances. Since 1 September 2008, appeals from the Small Claims Division are now heard in the District Court: LCA 2007 s 39(2) .

“Implicit in the concept of (natural justice or) fair adjudication lie two cardinal principles, namely, that no man shall be a judge in his own cause (nemo judex in causa sua), and that no man shall be condemned unheard (audi alteram partem)”: Halsbury's Laws of England, 4th ed, Reissue, Vol 1(1), Butterworths 1989, para 84 p 157.

“It is a principle of justice that a decision-maker, at least one exercising public power, must ordinarily afford a person whose interests may be adversely affected by a decision an opportunity to present material information and submissions relevant to such a decision before it is made. The principle lies deep in the common law. It has long been expressed as one of the maxims which the common law observes as ‘an indispensable requirement of justice’. It is a rule of natural justice or ‘procedural fairness’. It will usually be imputed into statutes creating courts and adjudicative tribunals”: Allesch v Maunz (2000) 203 CLR 172; 173 ALR 648; [2000] HCA 40; BC200004312 at [35] per Kirby J.

Consideration of the principles of natural justice (or, as it is now commonly referred to, procedural fairness) may be found in O'Keefe J's judgment in Wakim v Mathiew Pty Ltd (t/as Dove Migration Services) [2002] NSWSC 405; BC200202361 at [20] [30] . His comments were cited with approval by Harrison M in McCorkindale v Delamont [2002] NSWSC 540; BC200203361 , citing S A De Smith, Judicial Review of Administrative Action, 2nd ed, Stevens, London, 1968, pp 180–1. In McCorkindale, the issue was whether the appellant's solicitor had been given a reasonable opportunity to make submissions. The court held that she had, but either misunderstood or did not properly hear what the magistrate said. The magistrate cannot be expected to anticipate that a solicitor actually wished to say something further if there is no indication made by that solicitor.

Natural justice generally requires that persons liable to be directly affected by proposed administrative acts, decisions or proceedings be given adequate notice of what is proposed, so that they may be in a position: (a) to make representations on their own behalf; or (b) to appear at a hearing or inquiry (if one is to be held); and (c) effectively to prepare their own case and to answer the case (if any) they have to meet.

It has been said that it is also a breach of the rules of natural justice for a tribunal to act upon evidence which has no probative value: R v Deputy Industrial Injuries Cmr; Ex parte Moore [1965] 1 QB 456 at 476, 488; [1965] 1 All ER 81 at 87, 94 . See also Boyd v Carroll (NSWSC, Clarke J, No 14269/85, 21 October 1985, unreported, BC8500466) . It is also considered a tenet of natural justice that a court or other tribunal exercising judicial power has a duty to act fairly and to give the parties reasonable notice of the hearing: Brack v Wills [1977] 1 NSWLR 456 ; Hoggard v Worsborough Urban District Council [1962] 2 QB 93 ; Delta Properties Pty Ltd v Brisbane City Council (1955) 95 CLR 11; [1955] ALR 869; BC5500420 ; Commissioner of Police v Tanos (1958) 98 CLR 383; 31 ALJR 933. Although the Small Claims Division may not be exercising judicial power in the strict sense, it is submitted that such a rule of elementary fairness will apply equally in the Small Claims Division as to any other tribunal. For a discussion concerning the general principles relating to natural justice and its denial, see Halsbury's Laws of England, above, Vol 1(1), pp 157–194.

The ultimate test in determining whether natural justice has been afforded to the parties is whether each party has been given a fair opportunity to put its case and point of view: Beveridge v Dontan Pty Ltd (1991) 23 NSWLR 13; 24 ALD 196 , a case concerned with natural justice in the context of a reference under the former Pt 72 of the Supreme Court Rules 1970, but equally applicable in the present context. Relevant factors to consider are the nature of the issues, the submissions made by the parties, and the absence or otherwise of a request for an oral hearing and for an opportunity to cross-examine. Consideration of the rules of natural justice as they apply to proceedings in the Small Claims Division was given by Assessor Henderson in Datamatic Pty Ltd v Bankstown City Council (Downing Centre Local Court, 3961/1992, September 1992, unreported).

Denying a person the right to call admissible evidence which that person wishes to call to rebut a claim or charge is a denial of natural justice: HG v R (1999) 197 CLR 414; 160 ALR 554; [1999] HCA 2; BC9900188 at [97] per McHugh J; as is denying a party the right to tender admissible evidence in support of his or her claim: Hamod v Suncorp Metway Insurance Ltd [2006] NSWCA 243; BC200606830 (though this was not the finding on the facts of the case), or denying an adjournment where the refusal of the adjournment may be said to bring about a miscarriage of justice: HG v R (1999) 197 CLR 414 ; 160 ALR 554; [1999] HCA 2; BC9900188 at [100] per McHugh J. For the purposes of the appeal, the appellant will need to demonstrate legal error, not merely an erroneous ruling, and the error must be material to the outcome of the decision appealed from; that is, the decision must be one which is ‘vitiated by error’: Hamod v Suncorp Metway Insurance Ltd, above at [11]; Leichhardt Municipal Council v Seatainer Terminals Pty Ltd (1981) 48 LGRA 409 at 419 (cited with approval in Yates Property Corp Pty Ltd (in liq) v Darling Harbour Authority (Paddy Markets case) (1991) 24 NSWLR 156 at 177; 73 LGRA 47 per Handley J).

The requirements of natural justice also extend to the obligation to give reasons for the finding the magistrate (or assessor) is making: Housing Commission (NSW) v Tatmar Pastoral Co Pty Ltd [1983] 3 NSWLR 378; (1983) 53 LGRA 325 ; Yates Property Corp Pty Ltd (in liq) v Darling Harbour Authority (Paddy Markets case) (1991) 24 NSWLR 156; 73 LGRA 47 ; Stoker v Adecco Gemvale Constructions Pty Ltd [2004] NSWCA 449; BC200408635 at [41] per Santow J; Alchin v Daley [2009] NSWCA 418; BC200911470 at [35] per Sackville AJA (McColl, Young AJA agreeing) and the authorities cited at [36.2.10] . This obligation extends to the Small Claims Division: Gould v Kok (NSWSC, Young J, No 10708/94, 23 May 1994, unreported, BC9402556); McClymont v The Owners-Strata Plan No 12139 [2009] NSWSC 276; BC200902727 at [30] per McCallum J. As to the judicial obligation to give reasons, see [36.2.5] , [36.2.10] , [LCA07 s 7.15.5] . In Kells v Waters [2007] NSWSC 885; BC200706422 , an appeal on the grounds of denial of natural justice in the Small Claims Division was upheld in circumstances where the assessor did not explain how the plaintiff had made out his claim when it was conceded that he had not rendered a bill in proper form, nor how the amount for which she entered a verdict was calculated. An assessor is not required to give lengthy or elaborate reasons addressing every point in detail: Pender Robwenphi Pty Ltd [2008] NSWSC 1144; BC200809572 at [56] per Hall J; McClymont v The Owners-Strata Plan No 12139 [2009] NSWSC 276; BC200902727 at [36] per McCallum J. See also [LCA07 s 7.15.5] “The delivery of reasons”.

After an appeal to the Supreme Court in its Common Law Division, there is no further right of appeal to the Court of Appeal without leave: Supreme Court Act s 101(2)(h) ; Azriel v Sfhir (NSWCA, Meagher, Sheller, Powell JJA, CA 40297/93, 28 March 1993, unreported, BC9601078), where leave to appeal was refused.

There are a number of instances where appeals have been taken to the Supreme Court on the basis of an alleged denial of natural justice: El-Najjaar v Offshore Marketing Services [2003] NSWSC 209; BC200301314 ; KSM Transport Services Pty Ltd v Gregory’s Transport Pty Ltd [2003] NSWSC 901; BC200305869 (both decisions of Malpass M); Owners of Strata Plan No 2699 v Irving [2003] NSWSC 1172; BC20030765 ; Pegler v King [2004] NSWSC 668; BC200404781 (both decisions of Harrison M). In each case, the appeal was unsuccessful, the appellate jurisdiction being of the view that each side had been given the opportunity to present their case and make submissions. The court also took into account the objects of the Small Claims Division, being to provide an expeditious resolution of small claims with as little formality and technicality as possible. In Thorpe v Vatner [2004] NSWSC 619; BC200404565 the plaintiff was denied an adjournment and appealed to the Supreme Court on the basis that he was denied natural justice. A Bankruptcy Act 1966 (Cth) Pt X arrangement, which would have stayed the proceedings, was ineffective owing to incorrect execution, but the plaintiff proceeded on the basis that the arrangement was effective and applied for an adjournment. He appealed to the Supreme Court on the basis that he was refused an adjournment and was not in a position to present his case. Master Malpass (as he then was) held that the plaintiff assumed the risk that the adjournment might be refused and dismissed the appeal.
And in the same context:

AJ Mills & Sons Pty Ltd v WTH Pty Ltd [2004] NSWSC 1075; BC200407639 (plaintiff not denied procedural fairness by assessor’s refusal of adjournment for plaintiff to join third party; allegation of bias by assessor not made out);
Hartnett v Hoyn [2005] NSWSC 1108; BC200509448 per Malpass AJ (plaintiff chose not to attend hearing after late application for adjournment by telephone refused; no denial of natural justice);

Casali v Broderix [2005] NSWSC 1325; BC200511050 per Harrison AJ (alleged that magistrate misunderstood action; no denial of natural justice as magistrate considered all issues put in dispute by parties);

Rahman v Edward T David & Co Pty Ltd t/as Davis Breene Conti (Solicitors) [2005] NSWSC 1251; BC200510621 per James J (claimed professional misconduct does not suggest error of law involving lack of jurisdiction or denial of natural justice);

Osman v Local Court (Civil Claims) Bankstown [2004] NSWSC 1146; BC200408592 per Harrison M (claimed amount loaned in excessive of small claims division jurisdictional limit; whether jurisdiction to hear appeal; no error demonstrated; appeal dismissed);
Murray v Hay [2000] NSWSC 190; BC200002078 per Hidden J (whether denial of natural justice; natural justice denied; magistrate’s decision correct nonetheless; appeal dismissed).

Numerous other instances abound of attempts to dress up what is really a sense of dissatisfaction with the court’s rulings on procedural rulings or findings on matters of fact as a denial of natural justice and in some instances even lack of jurisdiction. (Note that the headings below are those of the editor). A case in point is Stojanovski v Parevski [2004] NSWSC 1144; BC200408624 (Malpass M (as he then was)) (alleged denial of natural justice said to arise from magistrate’s refusal to admit tender of witness statement not served in accordance with the court’s directions and to grant adjournment). In finding no error demonstrated, Malpass M commented that:

[14] The intention of the Parliament. The parliament has limited the grounds of appeal from matters dealt with in the Small Claims Division. The intention was to achieve finality in small claims and restrict that which could be the subject of an appeal. It was not intended to extend the scope of denial of natural justice so as to embrace matters that could be regarded as errors of fact and/or law.

[15] Procedural fairness is a flexible concept. The onus rests with the plaintiff to demonstrate entitlement to relief. In determining whether or not there has been a denial of procedural fairness, the task for the court is to look at the particular circumstances of the case before it. Procedural fairness is a flexible concept. Each case can be expected to turn on its own circumstances. The onus rests with the plaintiff to demonstrate entitlement to relief. In this case, it is my view that such onus has not been discharged.

[17] The real basis of the appeal is unhappiness with rulings made in the Local Court which are beyond the scope of an appeal in the SCD. The substance of the appeal is an unhappiness with rulings made by the Local Court (the ruling to refuse both the tender and the adjournment application) that cannot be otherwise challenged by reason of the limited appellate entitlement (it cannot be challenged by reason of alleged error). In my view, the refusal of the application did not bring about a denial of natural justice. What it effectively saw was a refusal of applications for further indulgence.

[20] Error in point of law does not give rise to an appeal. This is another of the many cases that are brought before this court and dressed up in a presentation of denial of natural justice in an endeavour to circumvent the limited avenue of appeal that is available when matters are heard in the Small Claims Division. Error in point of law does not give rise to an appeal.

[21] Authorities of superior courts on the subject of refusal to grant an adjournment or to amend a pleading are of limited assistance in the SCD. In cases such as this, plaintiffs often quote authority of appellate courts dealing with questions such as the refusal of applications for an adjournment or to amend a pleading. Generally speaking, such authority is not of assistance where the court is dealing with a question of denial of natural justice. The considerations involved can be expected to be different.

[22] Objects of the SCD. It needs to be borne in mind that the object of the Division is to provide litigants with a fast, cheap and informal resolution of their small disputes. So that can be done, there needs to be strict compliance with orders of the court. Adjournments should be rare. The costs to the parties and the public are to be kept to a minimum. Because of the restriction on the awarding of costs in the Division, the prejudice or inconvenience that may result from, inter alia, granting an adjournment may not be met by an order for costs.

In the same context, see also Oliveri Legal Pty Ltd v Lohning International Pty Ltd [2004] NSWSC 987; BC200407187 (Malpass M); Habra v Reinke [2005] NSWSC 1090; BC200508854 (Malpass M). As regards the latter case, Malpass M noted:

[8] Error of law in the SCD does not give rise to an appeal It is perhaps necessary in this particular case to make it abundantly clear that error on the part of the Magistrate (even if it be error in point of law) will not assist the plaintiff. The relevant statutory provisions exclude it as a ground of appeal.

[18] Another instance of unhappiness with findings of fact. This is just another case in which a plaintiff is unhappy with findings of fact made in the Local Court and comes to this court in a misconceived endeavour to have a rehearing. Unfortunately, so many of these cases involve very small sums.

Another instance of the same scenario is Doucoure v Bartlett [2004] NSWSC 219; BC200401505 (Malpass M) (original claim one for damages to motor vehicle sustained in motor vehicle accident; challenge on the basis of denial of natural justice and lack of jurisdiction not made out).

In Hassett v Vrzina [2006] NSWSC 22; BC200600312 , the plaintiff did not comply with the court’s directions as regards the filing of witness statements. They were only filed on the morning of the hearing. At the plaintiff’s request, the defendant’s witnesses were directed at the review to attend for cross-examination, which they did. It was held that the tenor of the then Practice Note makes it clear that there was to be no cross-examination unless a direction has been given at the pre-trial review for the attendance of the particular witnesses for cross-examination. However, a direction given by a registrar at the pre-trial review does not bind the magistrate hearing the action; the procedure to be followed at the hearing is in the hands of the magistrate or assessor conducting that hearing. Whilst the fact that the parties were not given an opportunity to adduce evidence and make submissions may be said to constitute a denial of natural justice, this had no effect on the result in the case, since the plaintiff had not complied with the directions to file and exchange his witness statements within time, and they were rightly excluded). For another instance of the same scenario, see Lawrence Bower Architects Pty Ltd v Goth [2006] NSWSC 805; BC200606366 per Associate Justice Harrison (it was open to the Magistrate to disallow further evidence from both parties; decision was in accordance with the Practice Note; the parties had a reasonable opportunity to present their evidence and make submissions; no denial of natural justice).

An elaboration of the meaning of the concept of procedural fairness in the context of the denial of the opportunity to receive a fair trial appears in Nominal Defendant v Saleh (2011) 57 MVR 412; [2011] NSWCA 16; BC201102212 at [16]–[27] per McColl JA (Beazley, Giles JJA agreeing).

level.toc-caption: [22,010.115] Further judicial pronouncements upon the general principles applicable in the SCD.

heading.title: Further judicial pronouncements upon the general principles applicable in the SCD.

p.text: The requirements of natural justice do not mandate an oral hearing in every case: Kojima Australia Pty Ltd v Australian Chinese Newspapers Pty Ltd [2000] NSWSC 1153; BC200007817 .
Similarly, the requirements of natural justice may not confer on a party the right to cross-examine in a given case: Kojima , above.

“There may, however, be cases in which the denial of an oral hearing or of the right to cross-examine may constitute a denial of natural justice. In determining whether that is or is not so in a given case, it is necessary to consider the whole of the circumstances including the legislation, the general practice as understood by the parties and any agreement as to the way in which the proceedings are to be conducted. It is for the relevant tribunal, in this case the Small Claims Division of the Local Court, to determine this in the light of its obligation to act fairly”: Kojima , above at [32]; McClymont v The Owners-Strata Plan No 12139 [2009] NSWSC 276; BC200902727 at [39] per McCallum J (in the circumstances of the case, the prohibition on cross-examination did not result in a denial of natural justice).

While the rules of natural justice do not generally require an oral hearing, in particular cases an oral hearing may be required where, for example, there is a real issue of credibility or a significant conflict of evidence. While the requirements of natural justice do not dictate a right to cross-examine, the circumstances of the case (the issues combined with the issue of credibility; the importance of the evidence of a particular witness; the amount involved) may make it essential that the evidence of a particular witness be tested by cross-examination. “Giving due weight to the policy of the [Small Claims Tribunal Act] to provide a forum for the expeditious and inexpensive resolution of disputes, I do not consider that justice could be done in this case without giving the respective parties the right to cross-examine one another”: Ex parte Burns (WASC, Full Court, Lib No 980154, 6 April 1998, unreported, BC9801143).

It is a denial of natural justice to refuse a party the opportunity to address the court on the written material tendered: Murray v Hay [2000] NSWSC 190; BC200002078 . It is also a denial of natural justice to refuse a party the opportunity to cross-examine: Spencer v Elichung Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 523; BC200604072 .

There is no problem with the court reading the written material, hearing them speak to it, and then giving judgment later, if the parties agree to this course. “No doubt, it is a practical approach to cases of this kind and is consistent with the injunction in s 23B(1) of the Local Courts (Civil Claims) Act that proceedings in the Small Claims Division `be conducted with as little formality and technicality as the proper consideration of the matter permits'”: Cohen v Blair [2000] NSWSC 1076; BC200007070 .

A party has a right to be represented by a solicitor or barrister in the Small Claims Division under the repealed s 11 of the Local Courts (Civil Claims) Act (now UCPR r 7.1 ), and it is not correct to say that a solicitor only has a limited right of appearance and that right did not include a right of audience: Warren v Maughan (NSWSC, Sharpe J, 28 August 1992, unreported).

There is nothing inherent in the procedure adopted by the Small Claims Division in the provisions of a Practice Note (No 3 of 2001) (and in particular that portion of it requiring the determination of the proceedings on the basis of written statements) that runs counter to the requirements of natural justice: Wakim v Mathiew Pty Ltd (t/as Dove Migration Services) [2002] NSWSC 405; BC200202361 . See also McCorkindale v Delamont [2002] NSWSC 540; BC200203361 .

“There is a perceptible distinction between the express words in s 69(2A) [now LCA 2007 s 39(2) ] “lack of jurisdiction” and concepts of jurisdictional error which have developed in relation to tribunals. The Small Claims Division is an element of a court and, although its proceedings are conducted in a deliberately informal manner, it is not of the nature of an administrative tribunal”: Saqa v Bainivalu [2005] NSWSC 1091; BC200508904 at [20] , per Grove J (plaintiff’s contention that “the broader grounds of jurisdictional error which can be relied upon when challenging a tribunal’s decision are also applicable to the Small Claims Division withdrawn, the plaintiff conceding that such a view is contrary to the current weight of authority”).

Where directions have been given pursuant to the relevant Practice Note that the hearing is to proceed on the exchange of written statements, it is procedurally unfair to admit on the day of the hearing documents produced under subpoena without giving a party affected by the substance of those documents the right to call evidence in rebuttal: Wende v Finney [2005] NSWSC 927; BC200506931 per Howie J.

[27] Of course informality and the abandonment of the normal rules of evidence and procedure should not be allowed to give rise to unfairness even where the justice being administered is in relation to relatively trivial claims. Rather in such matters the court might need to be particularly astute to ensure that the lack of formality and the speedy resolution of claims does not become an end in itself at the expense of the appearance of fairness to the parties within the court’s jurisdiction. After all the formal rules of procedure that normally attend a hearing are generally aimed at producing fairness to the parties, sometimes at the expense of efficiency in the exercise of the court’s jurisdiction. So where those rules are displaced by the need to provide cheap, efficient and expedient justice to the parties, the advantages can sometimes be obtained at too high a price so far as a particular litigant is concerned.

[28] No doubt one of the reasons why the proceedings in the Small Claims Division are conducted with the informality required is that the parties before the court are, in advance of the hearing, aware of the material upon which the determination is to be made. There are procedures laid down and referred to in the Practice Note that require the parties to identify to each other the material they intend to rely upon. The material upon which each side relies, including statements of witnesses and the actual documents at the heart of the dispute, are in a form where they can be reviewed by the court assisted by such submissions that the parties wish to make upon those documents without the need to formally tender and prove the relevant material. As the Magistrate in the present matter observed, the intention of the scheme of the relevant legislation is that the dispute can generally be resolved on the documents.
Note that under UCPR r 7.3(3) , no subpoena may be issued in the SCD “except by leave of the court in any circumstances.”

An absence of evidence to support a finding of fact can give rise to a denial of natural justice in proceedings dealt with in the SCD: assumed by Malpass AJ upon limited argument in Maitland City Council v Murdoch [2005] NSWSC 726; BC200505703 in the context of the then extant Practice Note (No 3 of 2001) (see now Practice Note Civ 1 of 2011).

The fact that documents raised suggestions of impropriety, if not criminality, against a party does not mean that the case is unsuitable for disposal in the SCD, nor that the magistrate lacks jurisdiction to deal with the claim, in particular where no application has been made for the claim to be transferred to the GD: Wende v Finney [2005] NSWSC 927; BC200506931 at [23] , per Howie J.

“The party challenging a decision of the Local Court bears the onus of satisfying the court that the decision should not be disturbed. It is not sufficient to merely demonstrate error”: Maitland City Council v Murdoch, above,at [26], per Malpass AJ. In any event, the magistrate had jurisdiction to entertain the claim, which was one for debt on the basis on the common money count for moneys had and received where money is paid under mistake of fact: at [20].

The failure to give advance notice of the delivery of a reserved decision (or, semble, one given in open court) does not constitute a want of jurisdiction or a denial of natural justice: McClymont v The Owners-Strata Plan No 12139 [2009] NSWSC 276; BC200902727 at [69] per McCallum J (Held: no difference to the outcome of the case): see [22,010.60] .

level.toc-caption: [22,010.120] Strata Schemes Management Act 1996 s 80 — Recovery of costs, expenses and interest

heading.title: Strata Schemes Management Act 1996 s 80 — Recovery of costs, expenses and interest

p.text: The Court of Appeal’s decision in Owners of Strata Plan 36131 v Dimitriou [2009] NSWCA 27; BC200900947 is authority for the proposition that the Small Claims Division of the Local Court does not lack jurisdiction to determine an owners corporation’s claim under Strata Schemes Management Act 1996 s 80 for its legal costs incurred in recovering unpaid contributions: McClymont v The Owners-Strata Plan No 12139 [2009] NSWSC 276; BC200902727 at [29] per McCallum J.

level.toc-caption: [22,015] Restatement of provisions of the Civil Procedure Act 2005 which do not apply in the SCD

p.text: Legislation cited in [22,015] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 Parts 4, 5, s 38(3)(b), s 4, ss 60, 70, 87, 92, 98, Sch 1.
(NSW) Local Court Act 2007 Pt 3.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 1.5, 1.6, r 20.8, Sch 1.

heading.title: Restatement of provisions of the Civil Procedure Act 2005 which do not apply in the SCD

p.text: Under CPA s 4 and Sch 1 column 2, the Act applies to all civil proceedings under LCA 2007 Pt 3 . Under the UCPR rr 1.5 and 1.6 and Sch 1 column 3, the following provisions do not apply in the SCD:

Parts 4 and 5 of the Act (Mediation and Arbitration of Proceedings) and ss 60 (proportionality of costs), 70 (court’s power to dispense with the rules of evidence for proving matters not bona fide in dispute and to order a party to make admissions), 87 (protection against self-incrimination in relation to interlocutory matters), 92 (judgments for possession of land), 98 (court’s powers as to costs), and Division 5 of Part 6 (interim payments).

However, notwithstanding the embargo on referrals to arbitration, UCPR r 20.8 states that for the purposes of CPA s 38(3)(b) , proceedings in the SCD may not be referred to arbitration unless the parties consent or the court finds that there are special circumstances to justify their referral. On would anticipate that, in the event of conflict, the Act would take precedence over the Rules.

level.toc-caption: [22,020] Restatement of provisions of the Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 which do not apply in the SCD by virtue of UCPR rr 1.5 and 1.6 and Sch 1, column 4

p.text: Legislation cited in [22,020] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.

(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Part 11, Part 13, Part 15, Part 16, Part 17, Part 18, Part 20, Parts 21, 22, Part 23, Parts 24, 25, 26, 27, 28, 29, Parts 31, 32, 33, Part 34, Part 39, Parts 40, 41, Part 44, Part 5, Divs 2, Divisions 3, 4, 6, Rules 14.4, 14.5, Rules 15.7, 15.8, Rule 16.4, r 23.8, r 36.15, r 36.16, r 36.16(2), r 36.8, r 43.6, r 44.1.

heading.title: Restatement of provisions of the Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 which do not apply in the SCD by virtue of UCPR rr 1.5 and 1.6 and Sch 1, column 4

p.text: Part 5 (Preliminary Discovery and Inspection)

Part 7, Divs 2 and 6 (Part 7 deals with parties to proceedings and representation). Division 2 “Representation” deals with representation of concurrent interests, representation of cases concerning administration of estates, trust property or statutory interpretation, beneficiaries and interests of deceased persons); Division 6 — deals with Relators. Divisions 3 “Executors, Administrators and Trustees” and 4 “Persons under legal incapacity” do apply.
Part 11 (Service of Documents outside Australia)
Part 13 (Summary Disposal)
Rules 14.4 and 14.5 (Part 14 — Pleadings; r 14.4 — Reply; r 14.5 — further pleadings)
Rules 15.7 and 15.8 (Part 15 deals with particulars; r 15.7 – Claims for exemplary damages; r 15.8 – Claims for exemplary damages).
Part 15 , Division 2 (Personal Injury cases)
Rule 16.4 ( Part 16 deals with Default Judgment; r 16.4 — Default judgment on claim for possession of land).
Part 17 (Admissions)

Part 18 (Motions), except in relation to an application under r 23.8 (Inspection of Property), r 36.15 General power to set aside judgment or order on sufficient cause if the judgment was given or entered, or the order was made, irregularly, illegally or against good faith), r 36.16 (Further power to set aside or vary judgment or order if notice of motion is filed before entry of the judgment or order, or after it has been entered in certain other circumstances as set out in r 36.16(2) ), or r 43.6 (Part 43 deals with Interpleader proceedings; r 43.6 — Interpleader motion).

Part 20 (Resolution of proceedings without hearing, Divisions 1 (Mediation), 2 (Arbitration), 3 Reference to referees) and 4 (Compromise). (But note that Division 5 — Judgment by agreement) and Division 6 (Acknowledgment of liquidated claim) do apply.
Parts 21 (Discovery, inspection and notice to produce documents before hearing) and 22 Interrogatories) (Note, however, that Part 34 “Notice to Produce at hearing” does apply in the SCD).

Part 23 (Medical examinations and inspection of property), Divisions 1 (medical examination) and 2 (Rehabilitation assessment) – but note that Divisions 3 (Inspection of property) and Division 4 (Consequences of default in compliance with Part) do apply.
Parts 24 (Taking evidence otherwise than at trial), 25 (Interim preservation), 26 (Receivers), 27 (Disposal of land), 28 (Separate decision of questions and consolidation) and 29 (trials).
Parts 31 (Evidence), 32 (Evidence and Procedure (New Zealand) Act 1994 (Commonwealth) and 33 (Subpoenas).
Rule 36.8 . Part 36 deals with judgments and orders. Rule 36.8 deals with Possession of land.

Part 39 , Division 2. Part 39 deals with enforcement of judgments. Division 2 deals with enforcement of writs against land. Division 1 (enforcement of writs of execution generally), Division 3 (enforcement of writs against goods), Division 4 (garnishee orders), Division 5 (charging orders) and Division 6 (general) do apply.
Parts 40 (Additional measures for enforcing judgments and orders of the Supreme Court and District Court, and 41 (Funds in Court).

Part 44 (Transfer of Proceedings under Part 9 of the Civil Procedure Act 2005, cross-vesting laws and transfers under other legislation), except for r 44.1 (deals with transfer of proceedings between Local Courts).

The following is a flow chart outlining the procedure in the Small Claims Division prepared by retired Assessor Graeme Roberts, formerly the States most senior Small Claims Assessor. His contribution is gratefully acknowledged.
Typical assessor's notes at a pre-trial review:
FILE NO: 61689/94
Peter McNamara v Manuel Pizzaro
Mr O'Shea (Solicitor) represented the plaintiff and the defendant appeared unrepresented.
Motor vehicle damages.

The defendant offered the plaintiff $1500 in full settlement of his claim on 15/9/91. The statement of claim was filed on 19/9/91, the day upon which the defendant's letter of offer was received. $1500 was unacceptable to the plaintiff and he instructed his solicitor to proceed on the statement of claim.

The plaintiff's representative said the defendant collided with the rear of his client's vehicle. The defendant says he simply cannot see how so much damage resulted from the collision as he was travelling at 5 kmh. He says there was no damage to his vehicle.
The defendant admitted there was a motor vehicle collision in which his vehicle collided with the rear of the plaintiff's vehicle. He denies the quantum of the plaintiff's claim.

I directed the matter proceed informally in the Court's Small Claims Division and that any evidence be in statement or documentary form. The plaintiff is to provide documentary evidence of the damage and serve copies of that and any statements on the defendant prior to the hearing. The defendant is to do likewise in respect of a statement from his wife who was a passenger in his vehicle as to her assessment of the damage occasioned. The defendant is to bring with him a Spanish interpreter.
Matter adjourned for hearing on 8 March 1995 at 9.30 am in court
(Small Claims Division)
Assessor/Registrar
[date]
FILE NO: 68463/94
New Millennium Architects Pty Ltd v Alphonso Moreno and Rita Moreno
The plaintiff company was represented at the pre-trial review by Mr Magnifico an authorised officer of the company. Each of the defendants appeared unrepresented.
Professional town planning and architectural services rendered by the plaintiff to the defendants.

The parties indicated they had no prior settlement discussions. The defendants were adamant they simply had been overcharged and felt there was little room for negotiation with the plaintiff's representative.

The plaintiff's representative said his retainer of $550 had been paid and that the work he performed on the part of the defendants was in respect of an inspection of their premises, a letter or report to the council and various discussions by telephone with council officers on behalf of the defendants. He said his fees are assessed at $190 per hour and that he has time sheets and records which indicate the full fee for his services was $1680. He said, however, he had discounted that fee for the defendants because he believed his personnel had spent too much time on the matter.

The defendants said that they had previously made two submissions to council in respect of the approval they required to build a balcony on their premises. Included with those submissions had been photographs of similar approvals council had given in respect of neighbouring properties. They said the plaintiff simply used their photographs in his submission to council. The first defendant said he had asked Mr Magnifico for a firm quote and was told $550 and they were surprised when they were invoiced for the amount claimed.
All the first defendant said he wanted was a letter from Mr Magnifico and he says they now have been charged for things he did not request.
There was consensus that Mr Magnifico had done work on behalf of the defendants but there was no agreement as to the fee ultimately charged for those services.
I directed the matter proceed informally in the Court's Small Claims Division and that any evidence be in statement or documentary form.
Matter adjourned for hearing on 8 March 1995 at 9.30 am in court
Assessor/Registrar
[date]
FILE NO: 68429/94
Big Pool Services Pty Ltd v Robin (Male)
The possibility of settlement was explored. Parties given the opportunity to discuss the matter outside court.
No settlement reached. Parties do not agree to settle at all.
The Plaintiff claims the defendant's pool was “Chlorine washed” to the value of $500.00.
The plaintiff claims, this amount was agreed to by the defendant. The defendant denies this.
The defendant claims he paid $300.00 in cash in full satisfaction of this claim in about February, or March, 1991.
The defendant claims the original amount of $500.00 was the amount quoted by the plaintiff to “acid wash” the defendants pool.

The defendant claims an employee of the plaintiff attended his premises and agreed with the defendants wife to “wash” the pool for $300.00, this largely being due to the fact that another company had already done some of the work.
The plaintiff admits that a job invoice was not sent to the defendant until March, 1991.

The plaintiff admits that the pool was given a “chlorine wash” rather than an “acid wash” as initially agreed upon, however, the costs of both washes is the same, that is, $500.00. The plaintiff contends that a “chlorine wash” was more suited to the defendants type of pool.
The defendant admits that he does not have in his possession a receipt for the $300.00 paid in cash to the plaintiff. He cannot recall whether he received one or not.
The defendant admits the plaintiff gave an original quote over the phone of $500.00 to “acid wash” the defendant's pool.

The authorised officer of the plaintiff, Mr Wanstein was directed to make a statement as to the usual procedures concerning the receipt of money in his office, the rendering of quotations and as to the sequence of events of the job the subject of the claim.

The plaintiff was also directed to obtain a statement from “David” the employee who the defendant alleges came to an agreement with his wife over the price and the “chlorine wash”, and who the defendant alleges took the cash payment of $300.00.
The defendant was directed to make a statement as to the payment of the money and the agreement as to price.
The defendant was also directed to obtain a statement from his wife concerning the agreement to pay $300.00 and the agreement for the “chlorine wash”.
THE MATTER IS
ADJOURNED FOR HEARING
ON
IN COURT
Assessor/Registrar
